Description: LAN Airlines agreed to pay $9.4 million to settle a case relating to payments it authorized during a dispute with its union employees in Argentina. To settle the SEC's charges that it failed to keep accurate books and records and maintain adequate internal accounting controls, LAN agreed to pay $9.4 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Company: LAN Cargo S.A.  And Aerolinhas Brasileiras S.A.
Description: Three air cargo carriers, LAN Cargo S.A., Aerolinhas Brasileiras S.A., and EL AL Israel Airlines Ltd. each agreed to plead guilty and pay criminal fines totaling $124.7 million for their roles in a conspiracy to fix prices in the air cargo industry. Under the plea agreements, LAN Cargo, a Chilean company, and ABSA, a Brazilian company that is substantially owned by LAN Cargo, agreed to pay a single criminal fine of $109 million. EL AL, an Israeli company, agreed to pay a criminal fine of $15.7 million.

LATAM Airlines Group S.A., a commercial airline company based in Chile, agreed to pay a $12.75 million criminal penalty in connection with a scheme to pay bribes to Argentine union officials via a false consulting contract with a third-party intermediary in violation of the accounting provisions of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

Info Source: FAA proposes civil penalty to Chilean airline for carrying hazardous materials, Associated Press, April 4, 2000 (via Nexis).
